title: Mum warns against extreme dieting after daughter took slimming pills and died
text:
Lindsey Bone, 20, was found dead in her bed (Picture: SWNS/ Getty)

A bright student was found dead in her bed after going on a crash diet ahead of her holiday.

Lindsey Bone, 20, had been following the 5:2 diet and taking supplement tables of apple cider vinegar to suppress her appetite.

She was found unresponsive by her flatmates on April 5, with medics confirming she had died the night before.

Brighton and Hove Coroner Veronica Hamilton-Deeley heard that Lindsey had been taking anti-depressants and anxiety medication since her dad died in May 2018.

The University of Sussex student had then started a strict diet plan in the weeks before her death, including fasting and taking pills made from crushed, distilled and fermented apples.

Her fiancé Jamie told the inquest she had been anxious about an upcoming holiday and was determined to lose weight.

Lindsey’s diary, found by coroner’s officer Claire Rogers, contained rules she had given herself, such as ‘eat no more than 1,200 calories a day’ and ‘carbs only once a day if at all’.

The criminology student had been fasting in a bid to lose weight (Picture: SWNS)

She had also instructed herself to ‘stay at the library and don’t eat’, snack on fruit and ‘take your f***ing apple cider vinegar’.

The notebook included comments in which Lindsey was ‘very negative about herself’, Mrs Rogers said.

Dieting pills were also found in her room by police officers.

Lindsey’s mum, Mandy Bone, said her daughter ‘used to take a tablespoon [of cider vinegar] every time she ate’ several times a day for around two years.

She had been in contact with Lindsey in the weeks before she died, and knew from her messages that she had not eaten much on the day of her death.

Mrs Bone told the inquest: ‘She was just a wonderful, strong person. She wanted to get through university to honour her dad and do the best she could.

‘She had so many plans for the future and everything she wanted to do.’

Mrs Bone said she wanted to warn others, particularly young girls, about the dangers of extreme dieting, adding: ‘Please be careful.’

Lindsey’s body was examined by pathologist Dr Catherine Guy and most tests returned ‘normal’ results.

Mandy Bone issued a warning to other girls, telling them to ‘please be careful’ (Picture: Getty Images/ iStockphoto)

The prescribed anti-depressant and anxiety medication found in her system was described as not exceeding a ‘normal, therapeutic dose’.

Dr Guy stated that the only positive finding from blood tests was a ‘slightly high acid level in the blood’, which is called acidosis.

She said: ‘It was not at a level we would normally consider as a fatal level but it was a lot higher than usual.

‘Your body has a natural way of balancing acid and alkali and that can be affected by diet, very high protein and low fat diets, especially if there has been fasting.

Student wears 'Maddy is in my freezer' on T-shirt at bar crawl

‘Apple cider vinegar is a food supplement. There is not much information on the effect it could have. Obviously the vinegar is acidic and we don’t know how many she was taking at once.

‘The only serious effects in the past have been when people have had a lot of vinegar.’

It was noted that Lindsey’s supplements could have reacted with her medication, but the doctor deemed it unlikely.

Ms Hamilton-Deeley stated that Lindsey’s death was a ‘mystery’, stating that the only two conclusions would be natural causes or misadventure.

She continued: ‘On the balance of probability I can record it is likely cardiac arrhythmia. I don’t know what has caused it.

‘What might have contributed is the anxiety and depression because of what she had been prescribed. They might not be 100% good.

‘Any prescription carries an element of risk. We can’t avoid the risks we don’t know about.’

The coroner added: ‘We have talked about the apple cider vinegar but there were other things she took and there is the possibility that on that day, a day of dieting, there was some interaction but I don’t know.

Advertisement

‘I am going to leave the conclusion open and I can’t do anything but offer you condolences on the loss of an extraordinary young woman. It is not satisfactory but I fear it is the best I can do.’
